recipes.name: Khandvi
recipes.description: Thin, rolled, and tempered gram flour snacks, a staple in Gujarati cuisine.
instructions: In a large bowl, whisk together **1 cup besan (gram flour)**, **3 cups curd (yogurt)**, **1 cup water**, **1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder**, and **salt to taste** until a smooth, lump-free batter is formed.

Pour the batter into a heavy-bottomed pan and cook on medium-low heat, stirring continuously with a whisk or spatula. It's crucial to stir constantly to prevent lumps and sticking. Continue cooking until the mixture thickens considerably and starts leaving the sides of the pan (about 8-10 minutes).
Immediately pour thin layers of the hot mixture onto greased plates or a clean kitchen counter. Use a spatula to spread it as thinly and evenly as possible. Let it cool for 5-7 minutes until set.
Once cooled and set, cut the spread batter into strips about 1 to 1.5 inches wide. Carefully roll each strip tightly from one end to the other.

For tempering: In a small pan, heat **2 tablespoons oil**. Add **1 teaspoon mustard seeds** and let them splutter. Then add **a pinch of asafoetida (hing)** and **a few curry leaves**. You can also add **slit green chilies** if you like a little spice.
Pour the hot tempering evenly over the rolled khandvi. Garnish with fresh **chopped coriander leaves** and **grated coconut** (optional). Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Handvo
recipes.description: A savory cake made with mixed lentils and rice, flavored with spices.
instructions: Combine **1 cup rice**, **1/2 cup chana dal (split chickpeas)**, **1/4 cup urad dal (split black lentils)**, and **1/4 cup toor dal (split pigeon peas)**. Wash them thoroughly and soak in enough water overnight (or for at least 6-8 hours).

Drain the soaked rice and dals. Grind them into a thick, coarse batter using minimal water. The consistency should be like idli batter. Add **1 cup sour curd**, **salt to taste**, **1 teaspoon ginger paste**, and **1 teaspoon green chili paste**. Mix well and let it ferment in a warm place for 4-6 hours, or until it shows signs of fermentation (slight bubbles).

Just before preparing, add **1 cup grated bottle gourd (doodhi)**, **1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder**, **1 teaspoon red chili powder**, **1/2 teaspoon sugar**, and **a pinch of baking soda (or fruit salt like Eno)** to the fermented batter. Mix gently.

Heat **3 tablespoons oil** in a deep pan or Handvo cooker (traditionally cooked in a pressure cooker without the whistle or a deep non-stick pan). Add **1 teaspoon mustard seeds**, **1 teaspoon sesame seeds**, **a pinch of asafoetida**, and **a few curry leaves**. Let them splutter.

Pour the prepared batter into the tempered oil, spreading it evenly. You can sprinkle some more sesame seeds on top. Cover and cook on a low flame for 25-30 minutes, or until the bottom is golden brown and crispy.

Carefully flip the handvo (you can use a plate to assist) and cook the other side for another 15-20 minutes, or until cooked through and golden. Alternatively, you can bake it in a preheated oven at 180°C (350°F) for 40-50 minutes.
Cut into wedges and serve hot with **green chutney**.

recipes.name: Ghughra (Sweet Gujiya)
recipes.description: A crispy fried pastry stuffed with a sweet coconut and dry fruit filling.
instructions: For the outer shell: In a bowl, mix **2 cups refined flour (maida)** with **4 tablespoons ghee (clarified butter)**. Rub the ghee into the flour until it resembles breadcrumbs. Gradually add **cold water** to knead into a firm dough. Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.

For the filling: In a pan, lightly roast **1 cup grated fresh or desiccated coconut** until fragrant. Add **1/2 cup powdered sugar**, **1/2 teaspoon cardamom powder**, and **1/4 cup finely chopped dry fruits** (like almonds, cashews, raisins). Mix well and let it cool completely.
Divide the dough into small, equal portions. Roll each portion into a thin circle (about 3-4 inches in diameter).
Place a spoonful of the coconut filling on one half of the rolled circle, leaving the edges clear.

Lightly dampen the edges with water. Fold the other half of the circle over the filling to form a crescent shape. Press the edges firmly to seal. You can use a ghughra mould or crimp the edges with a fork for a decorative finish.
Heat **oil** for deep frying in a kadhai (wok) over medium heat. Once hot, carefully slide in a few ghughras, making sure not to overcrowd the pan.
Fry until they turn golden brown and crispy on both sides. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain excess oil on absorbent paper. Allow them to cool completely before storing in an airtight container.

recipes.name: Shrikhand
recipes.description: A creamy dessert made with strained yogurt and flavored with saffron and cardamom.
instructions: Take **4 cups fresh curd (yogurt)**. Place a large sieve over a bowl and line the sieve with a clean muslin cloth or cheesecloth. Pour the curd into the cloth. Gather the edges of the cloth and tie it to form a potli (pouch).
Hang this potli over a bowl in the refrigerator for 4-5 hours (or overnight) to drain all the excess whey (water). The thick, creamy substance left is called 'chakka' (hung curd).

Transfer the chakka to a mixing bowl. Add **1/2 to 3/4 cup powdered sugar** (adjust to your sweetness preference), **1/2 teaspoon cardamom powder**, and **a pinch of saffron strands** (soaked in 1 tablespoon warm milk for 10 minutes) to the chakka.

Whisk everything together thoroughly until the mixture is smooth, creamy, and lump-free. You can use a hand whisk or an electric beater. If you prefer a very smooth texture, you can pass it through a sieve.
Chill the shrikhand in the refrigerator for at least 1-2 hours before serving to allow the flavors to meld and for it to firm up.
Garnish with sliced **almonds** and **pistachios** before serving.

recipes.name: Khichu
recipes.description: A soft, steamed rice flour dish, often enjoyed as a snack.
instructions: In a heavy-bottomed pan, bring **2 cups water** to a boil. Add **1 teaspoon cumin seeds (jeera)**, **1-2 slit green chilies** (adjust to spice preference), **1/2 teaspoon asafoetida (hing)**, and **salt to taste**.

Once the water is boiling rapidly, reduce the flame to low. Gradually add **1 cup rice flour** in a continuous stream while stirring vigorously with a wooden spoon or whisk to prevent lumps. Continue stirring until all the flour is incorporated and the mixture starts to thicken.
Cover the pan and let it cook on very low heat for 5-7 minutes, allowing the rice flour to steam and become soft. Stir occasionally to ensure even cooking and prevent sticking.
Once cooked, the khichu will be soft, sticky, and well-combined. Turn off the heat.
Serve hot in a bowl, drizzled generously with **sesame oil** or **groundnut oil**. You can also sprinkle some **roasted cumin powder** and a pinch of **red chili powder** for extra flavor.

recipes.name: Dhokla
recipes.description: A savory steamed cake made from fermented rice and chickpea flour batter.
instructions: For the batter: In a large bowl, combine **1 cup rice flour** and **1/2 cup chickpea flour (besan)**. Gradually add **1.5 cups sour curd (yogurt)** and **1/2 cup water**, whisking continuously to form a smooth, lump-free batter. The consistency should be thick but pourable. Add **1 teaspoon ginger-chili paste**, **1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder**, and **salt to taste**. Mix well. Cover and let the batter ferment in a warm place for 6-8 hours or overnight.
Prepare the steamer: Grease a dhokla plate or a shallow baking tin with oil. Bring water to a boil in a steamer.

Just before steaming: Add **1 teaspoon Eno (fruit salt)** or **1/2 teaspoon baking soda** to the fermented batter. Pour 1 tablespoon of water over it to activate. Gently mix until bubbles form. Do not overmix.
Immediately pour the batter into the greased dhokla plate. Place it in the hot steamer. Cover and steam for 15-20 minutes, or until a knife inserted into the center comes out clean.
Remove from the steamer and let it cool slightly. Cut into squares or diamonds.

For tempering: In a small pan, heat **2 tablespoons oil**. Add **1 teaspoon mustard seeds** and let them splutter. Then add **1 teaspoon sesame seeds**, **a pinch of asafoetida (hing)**, and **a few curry leaves**. Add **2-3 slit green chilies** and sauté for a minute. Pour **1/4 cup water** and **1 teaspoon sugar** into the tempering and bring it to a boil. Turn off the heat.
Pour the hot tempering evenly over the cut dhokla pieces. Garnish with fresh **chopped coriander leaves** and **grated coconut** (optional). Serve hot with green chutney.

recipes.name: Sev Tameta Nu Shaak
recipes.description: A tangy and spicy curry made with tomatoes and topped with crispy sev.
instructions: In a kadhai or pan, heat **2 tablespoons oil**. Add **1 teaspoon mustard seeds** and let them splutter. Add **1 teaspoon cumin seeds** and let them crackle. Add **a pinch of asafoetida (hing)** and **a few curry leaves**.

Add **2 large onions** (finely chopped, optional, can be skipped for Jain version) and sauté until translucent. Then add **1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste** (or finely chopped ginger and garlic) and sauté until fragrant.
Add **3-4 large tomatoes** (finely chopped or pureed). Cook on medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the tomatoes soften and the oil starts separating (about 8-10 minutes).
Add powdered spices: **1 teaspoon red chili powder**, **1.5 teaspoons coriander powder**, **1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder**, and **salt to taste**. Mix well and cook for 2 minutes.

Add **1.5 to 2 cups water** (adjust to desired gravy consistency). Bring the curry to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 5-7 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld. Add **1 tablespoon jaggery (gur)** or **sugar** for a sweet and sour taste.
Just before serving, turn off the heat. Pour the hot shaak into a serving bowl. Garnish generously with **sev (crispy chickpea noodles)** and fresh **chopped coriander leaves**.
Serve hot with **rotis**, **parathas**, or **puri**.

recipes.name: Doodhpak
recipes.description: A traditional sweet rice pudding cooked in milk, often flavored with saffron and dry fruits.
instructions: Wash **1/4 cup basmati rice** and soak it in water for 15-20 minutes. Drain and keep aside.
In a heavy-bottomed pan or kadhai, pour **1 liter full-fat milk**. Bring the milk to a boil on medium heat, stirring occasionally to prevent scorching.

Once the milk boils, reduce the flame to low. Add the drained rice to the milk. Continue to cook on low heat, stirring frequently, until the rice is completely cooked and tender (about 25-30 minutes). The milk will also start to thicken.

Once the rice is soft, add **1/2 cup sugar** (adjust to sweetness preference), **1/2 teaspoon cardamom powder**, and **a pinch of saffron strands** (soaked in 1 tablespoon warm milk). Stir well to combine.

Add **1/4 cup chopped mixed dry fruits** (almonds, pistachios, cashews, raisins). Continue to simmer for another 10-15 minutes, stirring, until the doodhpak reaches a thick, creamy consistency. It will thicken further upon cooling.
Remove from heat and let it cool down. Serve doodhpak warm or chilled. Garnish with additional **chopped dry fruits**.

recipes.name: Puri Bhaji
recipes.description: Deep-fried puffed bread served with a spiced potato curry.
instructions: For the Puri: In a large bowl, combine **2 cups whole wheat flour (atta)** with **1/2 teaspoon salt** and **1 tablespoon oil**. Mix well. Gradually add **water** (about 3/4 to 1 cup) and knead into a stiff, smooth dough. The dough should be firmer than chapati dough. Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.

For the Bhaji (Potato Curry): Boil **3-4 medium potatoes** until tender. Peel and cut them into medium-sized cubes. In a pan, heat **2 tablespoons oil**. Add **1 teaspoon mustard seeds** and **1 teaspoon cumin seeds**. Let them splutter. Add **a pinch of asafoetida (hing)**, **a few curry leaves**, and **2-3 slit green chilies**. Sauté for a minute.

Add **1 medium onion** (finely chopped, optional) and sauté until translucent. Add **1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder** and **salt to taste**. Add the boiled potato cubes and mix gently. Add about **1/2 cup water** to create a slight gravy. Simmer for 5-7 minutes. Garnish with fresh **chopped coriander leaves**.
To fry Puri: Heat **oil** for deep frying in a kadhai (wok) over medium-high heat. The oil should be hot enough but not smoking.

Divide the puri dough into small, equal portions. Lightly grease your rolling pin and surface. Roll out each portion into a small, thin circle (about 4-5 inches in diameter). Do not roll too thin or too thick.

Carefully slide a rolled puri into the hot oil. Gently press down with a slotted spoon to help it puff up. Once it puffs, flip and fry on the other side until light golden brown and crispy. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain excess oil on absorbent paper.
Serve hot puris immediately with the potato bhaji.

recipes.name: Aamras
recipes.description: Sweet and smooth pulp made from ripe mangoes, a seasonal summer delight.
instructions: Choose **2-3 ripe, sweet mangoes** (Alphonso, Kesar, or Dasheri varieties are ideal for aamras). Wash them thoroughly.
Peel the mangoes and chop the flesh into small pieces, discarding the seed.

Transfer the mango pieces to a blender or food processor. Add **2-3 tablespoons powdered sugar** (optional, adjust based on mango sweetness) and **1/4 cup chilled milk** or **water** if you prefer a thinner consistency. You can also add **1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder** for flavor (optional).
Blend until smooth and creamy, without any lumps. If you prefer a coarser texture, you can skip blending entirely and mash with your hands or a potato masher.
Transfer the aamras to a serving bowl. Chill in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes to an hour before serving for the best taste.
Serve chilled, often with hot **puris** or as a standalone dessert.

recipes.name: Patra / Alu Vadi
recipes.description: Steamed and rolled colocasia leaves smeared with a spicy-sweet gram flour paste, then tempered.
instructions: Gather **10-12 medium-sized colocasia leaves (arbi ke patte)**. Wash them thoroughly and pat dry. Carefully remove the prominent veins from the back of the leaves using a knife, being careful not to tear the leaves. This makes them pliable.

For the paste: In a bowl, combine **1 cup chickpea flour (besan)**. Add **2 tablespoons tamarind pulp** (or a small lime-sized ball of tamarind soaked in water and mashed), **2 tablespoons jaggery (gur)** (grated or powdered), **1 tablespoon ginger-chili paste** (or finely chopped ginger and green chilies), **1 teaspoon turmeric powder**, **1.5 teaspoons red chili powder**, **1.5 teaspoons coriander powder**, **1 teaspoon cumin powder**, **1/2 teaspoon asafoetida (hing)**, **2 tablespoons oil**, and **salt to taste**. Add enough **water** (about 1/2 cup) to make a thick, smooth, spreadable paste. Ensure there are no lumps.

Lay one colocasia leaf flat on a clean surface, with the darker side facing down. Spread a thin, even layer of the prepared besan paste over the entire surface of the leaf. Place another leaf on top, facing the opposite direction (tip to base), and spread paste on it. Repeat with 3-4 leaves to create a stack.

Fold the sides of the stacked leaves inwards (about 1-2 inches). Then, starting from the broad end, tightly roll the stack of leaves into a firm cylinder. Repeat for all leaves to form multiple rolls.

Grease a steamer plate with oil. Place the prepared patra rolls on the plate. Steam for 20-25 minutes, or until the rolls are cooked through and firm. A knife inserted should come out clean. Let them cool completely.
Once cooled, slice the steamed patra rolls into 1/2-inch thick discs.

For tempering: In a pan, heat **3 tablespoons oil**. Add **1 teaspoon mustard seeds** and **1 teaspoon sesame seeds**. Let them splutter. Add **a pinch of asafoetida** and **a few curry leaves**. Add the sliced patra pieces to the tempering and gently toss or shallow fry until they are lightly golden and slightly crispy on the outside.
Garnish with fresh **chopped coriander leaves** and **grated coconut** (optional). Serve hot with green chutney or as a snack.

recipes.name: Masala Chaas
recipes.description: Spiced buttermilk, a cooling and digestive drink.
instructions: In a blender or a large bowl, combine **1 cup fresh, cold curd (yogurt)** and **2 cups chilled water**. Blend or whisk thoroughly until smooth and frothy, ensuring there are no lumps.

Add the following spices and herbs: **1/2 teaspoon roasted cumin powder**, **1/4 teaspoon black salt (kala namak)**, **salt to taste**, **1 tablespoon finely chopped fresh coriander leaves**, and **1/2 teaspoon finely chopped green chilies** (optional, adjust to spice preference).
Blend or whisk again for a few seconds to combine all the ingredients.
Pour the masala chaas into serving glasses. You can add a few **ice cubes** if you prefer it extra chilled.
Garnish with a small sprig of **mint leaves** or a sprinkle of **cumin powder**. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Pav Bhaji
recipes.description: A popular fast food dish from Maharashtra, consisting of a spiced vegetable mash (bhaji) served with soft buttered bread rolls (pav).
instructions: For the Bhaji: Heat 2 tablespoons butter in a large pan or tawa. Add 1 finely chopped onion and sauté until translucent.
Add 1 finely chopped capsicum (bell pepper) and cook for 2-3 minutes. Then add 2-3 finely chopped tomatoes and cook until soft and pulpy.
Add 1 cup boiled and mashed potatoes, 1/2 cup boiled green peas, and 1/2 cup boiled cauliflower florets. Mix well.
Sprinkle 1-2 tablespoons pav bhaji masala, 1 teaspoon red chili powder, and salt to taste. Mix thoroughly.
Add 1/2 cup water (or more, for desired consistency) and mash the vegetables with a potato masher directly in the pan until smooth and well combined.
Cook for another 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the bhaji thickens and flavors meld. Garnish with fresh chopped coriander leaves and a squeeze of lemon juice.
For the Pav: Slit the pav horizontally, without cutting all the way through. Heat a tawa and apply butter generously on both sides of the pav.
Toast the pav on the tawa until golden brown and slightly crispy on both both sides.
Serve the hot bhaji with buttered pav, a wedge of lemon, and chopped onions.

recipes.name: Masala Dosa
recipes.description: A popular South Indian dish consisting of a crispy, thin pancake (dosa) made from fermented rice and lentil batter, filled with a spiced potato mixture (masala).
instructions: For the Dosa Batter: Soak 2 cups raw rice and 1/2 cup urad dal (black gram) separately for 4-6 hours. Grind them separately with a little water to a smooth batter. Mix both batters, add 1/2 teaspoon fenugreek seeds (methi), and let it ferment overnight (8-12 hours) in a warm place. The batter should be thick but pourable, with a slightly sour smell.
For the Potato Masala: Heat 2 tablespoons oil in a pan. Add 1 teaspoon mustard seeds, 1/2 teaspoon urad dal, and a few curry leaves. Let them splutter.
Add 1 finely chopped onion and sauté until translucent. Add 2-3 slit green chilies and 1/2 inch ginger (grated or finely chopped).
Add 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder and salt to taste. Mix well.
Add 3-4 boiled and mashed potatoes. Mix thoroughly, breaking any large lumps. Add 1/4 cup water if the mixture is too dry. Cook for 2-3 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Garnish with fresh chopped coriander leaves. Set aside.
For making Dosa: Heat a non-stick tawa or cast-iron griddle. Lightly grease it with oil and wipe off excess with a cloth.
Pour a ladleful of dosa batter in the center of the tawa and spread it outwards in a circular motion to form a thin, even circle.
Drizzle 1 teaspoon oil or ghee around the edges and on top of the dosa. Cook on medium heat until the edges start to crisp and turn golden brown.
Place a generous spoonful of potato masala on one half of the dosa. Fold the other half over the masala.
Cook for another minute until heated through. Carefully remove from the tawa.
Serve hot with coconut chutney and sambar.

recipes.name: Butter Chicken (Murgh Makhani)
recipes.description: A classic Indian curry made with tender chicken pieces cooked in a rich, creamy, and mildly spiced tomato-based gravy.
instructions: For Marinating Chicken: Cut 500g boneless chicken into bite-sized pieces. In a bowl, combine chicken with 2 tablespoons yogurt, 1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste, 1 teaspoon red chili powder, 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder, and salt to taste. Marinate for at least 30 minutes, or preferably 2-3 hours in the refrigerator.
For the Gravy: Heat 2 tablespoons oil and 1 tablespoon butter in a large pan or pot. Add 2 large chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add 2 teaspoons ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a minute until fragrant.
Add 4-5 large chopped tomatoes (or 1 cup tomato purée), 1/2 cup cashews, 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder, 1 teaspoon red chili powder, 1 teaspoon garam masala, and salt to taste. Mix well.
Add 1 cup water, cover, and cook until the tomatoes are soft and mushy (about 10-15 minutes). Let it cool down.
Once cooled, blend the mixture into a smooth paste. Strain the paste through a sieve for a silky smooth gravy.
Cooking the Chicken: In the same pan, add a little more oil/butter. Add the marinated chicken pieces and cook until they are lightly browned on all sides and partially cooked.
Pour the strained tomato-cashew gravy into the pan with the chicken. Add 1/2 cup water (or chicken stock) to adjust consistency.
Bring to a simmer. Add 1/4 cup fresh cream and 1 teaspoon kasuri methi (dried fenugreek leaves), crushed between your palms. Mix well.
Cover and cook on low heat for 10-15 minutes, or until the chicken is tender and cooked through, and the gravy has thickened to your desired consistency.
Garnish with fresh chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot with naan, roti, or rice.

recipes.name: Chole Bhature
recipes.description: A popular North Indian dish, especially beloved in Punjab and Delhi, consisting of spicy chickpea curry (chole) served with deep-fried leavened bread (bhature).
instructions: For Chole (Chickpea Curry): Soak 1 cup chickpeas (chole) overnight. Drain and pressure cook with 1 bay leaf, 2-3 cloves, 1 cinnamon stick, and 1 tea bag (for color) until soft (about 5-6 whistles). Discard whole spices and tea bag.
Heat 2 tablespoons oil in a pan. Add 1 teaspoon cumin seeds, 1 finely chopped onion, and sauté until golden brown. Add 1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.

Add 2 finely chopped tomatoes (or 1/2 cup tomato purée), 1 teaspoon red chili powder, 1 teaspoon coriander powder, 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder, 1 teaspoon chole masala, and salt to taste. Cook until oil separates.
Add the boiled chickpeas and mix well. Add 1/2 cup water (or more, as needed) and bring to a simmer. Cook for 10-15 minutes, mashing a few chickpeas to thicken the gravy.
Garnish with fresh chopped coriander leaves and a squeeze of lemon juice.

For Bhature: In a large bowl, mix 2 cups maida (all-purpose flour), 1/4 cup sooji (semolina), 1 teaspoon sugar, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1/4 teaspoon baking soda, and 1 tablespoon oil. Add 1/2 cup yogurt and gradually add water to knead a soft, smooth dough. Cover and let it rest for at least 1-2 hours (or overnight for best results).
Heat oil for deep frying in a kadai or deep pan.
Divide the dough into small balls. Roll out each ball into an oval or round shape, about 6-7 inches in diameter. Do not roll too thin.
Carefully slide the rolled bhatura into the hot oil. Gently press it down with a slotted spoon to puff it up. Flip and fry until golden brown on both sides.
Remove with a slotted spoon and drain excess oil on paper towels.
Serve hot chole with freshly fried bhature, sliced onions, and green chilies.

recipes.name: Rogan Josh
recipes.description: Aromatic Kashmiri lamb curry, characterized by its rich red color derived from dried Kashmiri chilies and lack of tomatoes, instead relying on a base of yogurt and aromatic spices.
instructions: For Marinating Lamb: Cut 500g lamb (preferably shoulder or leg) into 1.5-2 inch pieces. In a bowl, mix lamb with 1/2 cup yogurt, 1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste, 1 teaspoon red chili powder, and salt to taste. Marinate for at least 2 hours or overnight in the refrigerator.
For the Gravy: Heat 3 tablespoons mustard oil (or any cooking oil) in a heavy-bottomed pan or pressure cooker until it smokes. Let it cool slightly.
Add 1 teaspoon cumin seeds, 2-3 green cardamom pods, 2 black cardamom pods, 4-5 cloves, and 1 inch cinnamon stick. Sauté for a few seconds until fragrant.
Add 1 large onion, finely sliced, and sauté until golden brown.
Add the marinated lamb and brown it on all sides for 5-7 minutes.

In a small bowl, whisk together 1/2 cup yogurt with 1 teaspoon dry ginger powder (saunth), 1 teaspoon fennel powder (saunf), 1 teaspoon red chili powder (Kashmiri), and 1/2 teaspoon garam masala. Add a little water to make a smooth paste.
Reduce heat and add this spice-yogurt paste to the lamb. Stir continuously for 5-7 minutes to prevent curdling, until the oil separates.
Add 1 cup hot water or lamb stock. Season with salt if needed.

Cover and simmer on low heat for 45-60 minutes, or pressure cook for 3-4 whistles and then simmer for 15-20 minutes, until the lamb is tender and the gravy has thickened. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves (optional, as traditional Rogan Josh is not garnished with coriander). Serve hot with rice or naan.

recipes.name: Palak Paneer
recipes.description: A classic North Indian vegetarian dish featuring soft cubes of paneer (Indian cottage cheese) cooked in a vibrant and creamy spinach (palak) gravy.
instructions: Blanching Spinach: Wash 500g fresh spinach (palak) thoroughly. Bring a large pot of water to a rolling boil. Add the spinach and blanch for 2-3 minutes until wilted. Immediately transfer the spinach to a bowl of ice-cold water to retain its vibrant green color. Drain and blend into a smooth purée.
For the Gravy: Heat 2 tablespoons oil or ghee in a pan. Add 1 teaspoon cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add 1 finely chopped onion and sauté until light golden.
Add 1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste and 2-3 green chilies (slit or chopped). Sauté for a minute until fragrant.
Add 1/2 cup finely chopped tomatoes (optional, some prefer no tomatoes) and cook until soft and pulpy.
Add 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder, 1 teaspoon coriander powder, and salt to taste. Mix well.
Add the spinach purée and mix thoroughly. Bring to a simmer and cook for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the raw smell of spinach disappears.
Add 200g paneer, cut into cubes. Gently mix it into the spinach gravy. You can lightly pan-fry the paneer cubes before adding them for a firmer texture.
Add 1/4 cup fresh cream (or milk for a lighter version) and 1/2 teaspoon garam masala. Mix gently.
Simmer for another 5 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld. Do not overcook the paneer as it can become rubbery.
Serve hot with roti, naan, paratha, or rice.

recipes.name: Scrambled Eggs
recipes.description: A classic breakfast dish made by whisking eggs and cooking them gently in a pan, often with milk or cream.
instructions: Crack 2-3 large eggs into a bowl. Add a splash of milk or cream (about 1-2 tablespoons), and season with salt and black pepper to taste. Whisk vigorously with a fork until the yolks and whites are well combined and slightly frothy.
Heat a non-stick frying pan over medium-low heat. Add 1 teaspoon butter or oil and let it melt.
Pour the egg mixture into the heated pan. Let it sit undisturbed for about 30 seconds until the edges start to set.
Using a spatula, gently push the cooked egg from the edges towards the center, allowing the uncooked egg to flow underneath.
Continue gently folding and pushing the eggs until they are mostly set but still slightly moist and creamy. Avoid overcooking, as they can become dry.
Remove from heat immediately and serve hot. Garnish with fresh chopped chives or parsley if desired.

recipes.name: Omelette
recipes.description: A versatile egg dish made by beating eggs, cooking them flat in a pan, and folding them over various fillings.
instructions: Crack 2-3 large eggs into a bowl. Season with salt and black pepper. Whisk lightly with a fork until just combined, being careful not to incorporate too much air.
Heat a non-stick frying pan (preferably 8-inch) over medium heat. Add 1 teaspoon butter or oil and swirl to coat the pan.
Pour the egg mixture into the hot pan. Tilt the pan to spread the eggs evenly across the bottom.
As the edges set, gently push the cooked egg towards the center with a spatula, allowing the uncooked egg to flow underneath. Continue this until the top is mostly set but still a little moist.
Add your desired fillings (e.g., shredded cheese, cooked ham, sautéed mushrooms, chopped onions, bell peppers) evenly over one half of the omelette.
Carefully fold the other half of the omelette over the filling. Cook for another 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until the cheese is melted and the filling is heated through.
Slide the omelette onto a plate and serve immediately. Garnish with fresh herbs if desired.

recipes.name: Eggs Benedict
recipes.description: A classic American breakfast or brunch dish consisting of two halves of an English muffin, topped with Canadian bacon (or ham), a poached egg, and hollandaise sauce.
instructions: For Poached Eggs: Fill a medium pot with about 2-3 inches of water. Add 1 tablespoon white vinegar (optional, helps eggs hold shape) and bring to a gentle simmer (not a rolling boil).

Crack each cold egg into a separate small bowl or ramekin. Gently slide one egg at a time into the simmering water. Cook for 3-4 minutes for runny yolks, or longer for firmer yolks. Use a slotted spoon to remove the eggs and drain on paper towels.

For Hollandaise Sauce (Quick Method): In a heatproof bowl set over a saucepan of simmering water (bain-marie), whisk together 3 egg yolks, 1 tablespoon lemon juice, and a pinch of salt until slightly thickened.

Gradually whisk in 1/2 cup melted unsalted butter, a tablespoon at a time, continuously whisking until the sauce thickens and emulsifies. If it gets too thick, add a teaspoon of hot water. Season with a pinch of cayenne pepper (optional). Keep warm.
Assemble: Toast two halves of an English muffin. Top each half with a slice of Canadian bacon or ham, warmed gently in a pan.
Place a poached egg on top of the bacon/ham. Drizzle generously with hollandaise sauce.
Serve immediately, often garnished with chopped chives or paprika.

recipes.name: Paneer Tikka
recipes.description: Spiced, grilled Indian cottage cheese cubes, perfect as an appetizer or snack.
instructions: In a bowl, mix 1 cup yogurt, 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1 tsp garam masala, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp cumin powder, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1 tbsp lemon juice, and salt to taste to make a marinade.
Cut 1 cup paneer into 1-inch cubes. Add paneer, 1 diced bell pepper, and 1 diced onion to the marinade. Mix well and let it marinate for at least 1 hour in the refrigerator.
Preheat a grill or oven to 200°C (400°F). Thread marinated paneer, bell pepper, and onion onto skewers.
Grill or bake for 10-12 minutes, turning occasionally, until paneer is golden and slightly charred.
Sprinkle with chaat masala and garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with mint chutney.

recipes.name: Vegetable Biryani
recipes.description: A fragrant, layered rice dish with mixed vegetables and aromatic spices.
instructions: Rinse 1.5 cups basmati rice and soak for 30 minutes. Drain and set aside.
In a large pot, heat 3 tbsp ghee. Add 1 bay leaf, 2 cloves, 1 cinnamon stick, and 2 cardamom pods. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add 1 sliced onion and cook until golden. Add 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 1 minute.
Add 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, peas, cauliflower), 1 tsp biryani masala, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp red chili powder, and salt. Cook for 5 minutes.
Add soaked rice, 2.5 cups water, and a handful of chopped mint and coriander. Bring to a boil, then simmer covered on low heat for 15-20 minutes until rice is cooked.
Fluff the rice gently and garnish with fried onions and cashews. Serve with raita.

recipes.name: Masoor Dal
recipes.description: A comforting, spiced red lentil curry, commonly served with rice or roti.
instructions: Rinse 1 cup masoor dal (red lentils) thoroughly and soak for 15 minutes. Drain and set aside.
In a pressure cooker, heat 2 tbsp oil. Add 1 tsp cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add 1 chopped onion and sauté until golden. Add 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste and 1 chopped green chili, and cook for 1 minute.
Add 1 chopped tomato, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1 tsp coriander powder, and salt. Cook until tomatoes soften.
Add soaked dal and 3 cups water. Pressure cook for 2-3 whistles until dal is soft and mushy.
Temper with 1 tbsp ghee, 1/2 tsp garam masala, and fresh coriander. Serve hot with rice or roti.

recipes.name: Aloo Gobi
recipes.description: A flavorful stir-fry of potatoes and cauliflower with aromatic spices.
instructions: Heat 2 tbsp oil in a large pan. Add 1 tsp cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add 1 chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste and 1 chopped green chili, and cook for 1 minute.
Add 2 diced potatoes and 2 cups cauliflower florets. Stir well to coat with oil.
Add 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1/2 tsp garam masala, and salt to taste. Mix well.
Cover and cook on low heat for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until potatoes and cauliflower are tender.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot with roti or rice.

recipes.name: Gulab Jamun
recipes.description: Soft, syrupy milk-based dumplings, a classic Indian dessert.
instructions: In a bowl, mix 1 cup milk powder, 1/4 cup all-purpose flour, 1/4 tsp baking soda, and a pinch of cardamom powder.
Add 2 tbsp ghee and enough milk (about 3-4 tbsp) to form a soft dough. Knead gently until smooth.
Divide the dough into small balls (about 12-15), ensuring there are no cracks.
For syrup: In a pan, heat 2 cups sugar with 2 cups water and a few saffron strands. Boil until slightly thickened (about 5-7 minutes). Add 1/2 tsp cardamom powder and keep warm.
Heat oil in a deep pan over medium-low heat. Fry the dough balls until golden brown, turning gently for even cooking (about 4-5 minutes).
Remove and immediately soak in warm sugar syrup for at least 1 hour. Garnish with chopped pistachios and serve warm or at room temperature.

recipes.name: Samosa
recipes.description: Crispy, deep-fried pastries filled with spiced potatoes and peas.
instructions: For dough: Mix 2 cups all-purpose flour, 1/4 tsp salt, 1/4 cup oil, and enough water (about 1/2 cup) to form a stiff dough. Knead until smooth, cover, and rest for 30 minutes.
For filling: Boil 2 medium potatoes, peel, and mash coarsely. Heat 1 tbsp oil in a pan, add 1 tsp cumin seeds, and let them splutter.

Add 1 tsp ginger paste, 1 chopped green chili, 1/2 cup boiled peas, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1/2 tsp red chili powder, 1/2 tsp garam masala, and salt. Mix in mashed potatoes and cook for 2-3 minutes. Add chopped coriander and let it cool.
Divide dough into 8 balls. Roll each into a thin circle, cut in half, and form a cone. Fill with 1-2 tbsp of filling, seal edges with water, and shape into a triangle.
Heat oil in a deep pan over medium heat. Fry samosas until golden and crisp (about 5-7 minutes). Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with tamarind chutney or mint chutney.

recipes.name: Rasgulla
recipes.description: Spongy, soft cheese balls soaked in sweet sugar syrup, a Bengali delicacy.
instructions: Heat 1 liter milk in a pan until it boils. Add 2 tbsp lemon juice to curdle the milk. Stir until whey separates. Drain using a muslin cloth, rinse under cold water to remove lemon taste.
Knead the paneer (chenna) for 8-10 minutes until smooth and soft. Divide into 10-12 small balls.
For syrup: Boil 1.5 cups sugar with 4 cups water in a wide pan. Add 1/4 tsp cardamom powder and a few saffron strands.
Add chenna balls to the boiling syrup. Cover and cook on medium-high heat for 15-20 minutes until they double in size.
Let rasgullas cool in the syrup. Serve chilled or at room temperature, garnished with chopped pistachios.

recipes.name: Rajma Masala
recipes.description: A hearty North Indian kidney bean curry, best served with rice.
instructions: Soak 1 cup red kidney beans overnight. Drain and pressure cook with 3 cups water and a pinch of salt for 5-6 whistles until soft. Set aside.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan. Add 1 tsp cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add 1 chopped onion and sauté until golden. Add 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste and 1 chopped green chili, and cook for 1 minute.
Add 2 chopped tomatoes, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric, and salt. Cook until tomatoes are mushy.
Add cooked kidney beans with 1 cup of cooking water. Simmer for 10-15 minutes until the gravy thickens.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Vada Pav
recipes.description: A spicy potato fritter sandwich, a popular Mumbai street food.
instructions: Boil 2 medium potatoes, peel, and mash coarsely. Heat 1 tbsp oil in a pan, add 1 tsp mustard seeds, and let them splutter.
Add 1 tsp ginger paste, 1 chopped green chili, a pinch of asafoetida, and 1/2 tsp turmeric. Add mashed potatoes, 1 tsp chaat masala, and salt. Mix and cool.
Form the potato mixture into small balls. Make a batter with 1 cup gram flour, 1/4 tsp turmeric, a pinch of baking soda, salt, and water to form a thick consistency.
Dip potato balls in batter and deep-fry in hot oil until golden and crisp (about 4-5 minutes). Drain on paper towels.
Slice 4 pav buns, spread green chutney and tamarind chutney inside, place a vada, and serve with fried green chilies.

recipes.name: Malai Kofta
recipes.description: Creamy cottage cheese and potato dumplings in a rich tomato-based gravy.
instructions: For koftas: Mix 1 cup grated paneer, 1 boiled mashed potato, 2 tbsp cornflour, 1/4 tsp garam masala, and salt. Form into small balls.
Deep-fry koftas in hot oil until golden brown (about 3-4 minutes). Drain and set aside.
For gravy: Heat 2 tbsp oil, add 1 tsp cumin seeds, and let them splutter. Add 1 chopped onion and sauté until golden.
Add 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste, 2 pureed tomatoes, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric, and salt. Cook until oil separates.
Add 1/2 cup cream and 1/2 cup water. Simmer for 5 minutes. Add koftas just before serving.
Garnish with fresh coriander and a drizzle of cream. Serve with naan or rice.

recipes.name: Jalebi
recipes.description: Crispy, spiral-shaped sweets soaked in saffron-flavored sugar syrup.
instructions: Mix 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 tbsp cornflour, 1/4 tsp baking soda, and a pinch of turmeric with 3/4 cup yogurt and water to form a thick batter. Let it ferment for 8 hours or overnight.
For syrup: Boil 1.5 cups sugar with 1 cup water, a few saffron strands, and 1/4 tsp cardamom powder until one-thread consistency (about 7-8 minutes). Keep warm.
Heat oil in a wide pan over medium heat. Pour batter into a squeeze bottle or piping bag with a small nozzle.
Pipe spirals into hot oil and fry until crisp and golden (about 2-3 minutes per side).
Soak fried jalebis in warm syrup for 1-2 minutes. Remove and serve warm.

recipes.name: Baingan Bharta
recipes.description: A smoky roasted eggplant dish with spices, popular in North India.
instructions: Roast 1 large eggplant over an open flame or in an oven at 200°C (400°F) until soft and charred (about 15-20 minutes). Peel and mash.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan. Add 1 tsp cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add 1 chopped onion and sauté until golden. Add 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste and 1 chopped green chili, and cook for 1 minute.
Add 2 chopped tomatoes, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric, and salt. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Add mashed eggplant and cook for 8-10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve with roti or rice.

recipes.name: Poha
recipes.description: A light breakfast dish made with flattened rice, onions, and spices.
instructions: Rinse 2 cups poha (flattened rice) in water and drain. Set aside to soften for 10 minutes.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan. Add 1 tsp mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add 1 tsp cumin seeds and a few curry leaves.
Add 1 chopped onion and 1 chopped green chili. Sauté until onions are golden.
Add 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1/2 cup boiled peas, and salt. Mix in the softened poha and stir gently for 3-4 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander, a squeeze of lemon juice, and sev (optional). Serve hot.

recipes.name: Kadai Paneer
recipes.description: Paneer and bell peppers cooked in a spicy tomato-based gravy.
instructions: Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan. Add 1 tsp cumin seeds and 2 dried red chilies, and let them splutter.
Add 1 chopped onion and sauté until golden. Add 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add 2 pureed tomatoes, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric, and salt. Cook until oil separates.
Add 1 diced bell pepper and 1 cup paneer cubes. Stir in 1 tsp kasuri methi and 1/2 tsp garam masala.
Cook for 5-7 minutes until bell peppers soften. Garnish with fresh coriander and serve with naan.

recipes.name: Misal Pav
recipes.description: A spicy sprouted lentil curry served with pav buns, a Maharashtrian street food.
instructions: Soak 1 cup mixed sprouts (moong, matki) overnight. Pressure cook with 2 cups water for 2 whistles. Set aside.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan. Add 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp cumin seeds, and a few curry leaves. Let them splutter.
Add 1 chopped onion and sauté until golden. Add 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste and 1 chopped green chili, and cook for 1 minute.
Add 2 chopped tomatoes, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1 tsp misal masala, 1/2 tsp turmeric, and salt. Cook until tomatoes are mushy.
Add cooked sprouts and 1 cup water. Simmer for 10 minutes. Garnish with fresh coriander and farsan.
Serve with pav buns, chopped onions, and a lemon wedge.

recipes.name: Kheer
recipes.description: A creamy rice pudding flavored with cardamom and saffron.
instructions: Rinse 1/4 cup basmati rice and soak for 20 minutes. Drain and set aside.
Heat 1 liter milk in a heavy-bottomed pan. Add the soaked rice and simmer on low heat, stirring occasionally, for 30-40 minutes until rice is soft and milk thickens.
Add 1/2 cup sugar, 1/4 tsp cardamom powder, and a few saffron strands. Stir until sugar dissolves.
Add 2 tbsp chopped almonds and cashews. Cook for another 5 minutes.
Serve warm or chilled, garnished with more nuts and a pinch of saffron.

recipes.name: Vegetable Pulao
recipes.description: A simple one-pot rice dish with vegetables and mild spices.
instructions: Rinse 1 cup basmati rice and soak for 20 minutes. Drain and set aside.
Heat 2 tbsp ghee in a pan. Add 1 bay leaf, 2 cloves, 1 cinnamon stick, and 1 cardamom pod. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add 1 sliced onion and sauté until golden. Add 1 tsp ginger paste and 1/2 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, peas).
Add soaked rice, 2 cups water, 1/2 tsp turmeric, and salt. Bring to a boil, then simmer covered for 15-20 minutes until rice is cooked.
Fluff the rice and garnish with fresh coriander. Serve with raita.

recipes.name: Dahi Vada
recipes.description: Soft lentil dumplings soaked in yogurt and topped with chutneys.
instructions: Soak 1 cup urad dal for 4 hours. Drain and blend with a pinch of salt and 1/4 tsp cumin seeds into a smooth batter.
Heat oil in a deep pan. Drop spoonfuls of batter to form small vadas and fry until golden (about 4-5 minutes). Soak vadas in warm water for 10 minutes, then gently squeeze out water.
Whisk 2 cups yogurt with a pinch of salt and 1/2 tsp roasted cumin powder.
Place vadas in a serving dish, pour yogurt over them, and drizzle with tamarind chutney and green chutney.
Garnish with red chili powder, roasted cumin powder, and fresh coriander. Serve chilled.

recipes.name: Bhindi Masala
recipes.description: Stir-fried okra with spices, a popular Indian side dish.
instructions: Wash and dry 2 cups bhindi (okra). Trim ends and slice into 1-inch pieces.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan. Add 1 tsp cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add sliced bhindi and cook on medium heat for 8-10 minutes until slightly crisp.
Add 1 chopped onion, 1 tsp ginger paste, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric, and salt. Cook for 5-7 minutes until onions are golden.
Sprinkle 1/2 tsp garam masala and mix well. Garnish with fresh coriander and serve with roti.

recipes.name: Upma
recipes.description: A savory South Indian breakfast dish made with semolina and vegetables.
instructions: Dry roast 1 cup semolina (rava) on low heat until aromatic (about 5 minutes). Set aside.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan. Add 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp urad dal, and a few curry leaves. Let them splutter.
Add 1 chopped onion, 1 chopped green chili, and 1/2 tsp ginger paste. Sauté until onions are soft.
Add 1/2 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, peas) and cook for 3-4 minutes.
Add 2.5 cups water, salt, and bring to a boil. Gradually stir in roasted semolina, mixing to avoid lumps.
Cook on low heat for 5-7 minutes until water is absorbed. Garnish with coriander and serve hot.

recipes.name: Gajar Halwa
recipes.description: A rich carrot-based dessert cooked with milk and ghee.
instructions: Grate 4 cups carrots. Heat 3 tbsp ghee in a heavy-bottomed pan and add grated carrots.
Cook on medium heat for 10-15 minutes until carrots soften and release their juices.
Add 2 cups milk and simmer on low heat, stirring occasionally, for 20-25 minutes until milk reduces.
Add 3/4 cup sugar, 1/4 tsp cardamom powder, and 2 tbsp chopped nuts (almonds, cashews). Cook for 5-7 minutes until thick.
Garnish with more nuts and serve warm.

recipes.name: Fish Curry
recipes.description: A tangy and spicy South Indian fish curry with coconut milk.
instructions: Marinate 500g fish fillets with 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp red chili powder, and salt for 20 minutes.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan. Add 1 tsp mustard seeds and a few curry leaves. Let them splutter.
Add 1 chopped onion and sauté until golden. Add 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste and 1 chopped green chili, and cook for 1 minute.
Add 2 chopped tomatoes, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1 tsp red chili powder, and 1/2 tsp turmeric. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Add 1 cup coconut milk and 1/2 cup water. Simmer for 5 minutes. Add fish and cook for 8-10 minutes until done.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve with rice.

recipes.name: Idli
recipes.description: Steamed rice and lentil cakes, a South Indian breakfast staple.
instructions: Soak 2 cups idli rice and 1 cup urad dal separately for 6 hours. Blend rice with a little water to a slightly coarse batter, and urad dal to a smooth batter.
Mix both batters, add a pinch of salt, and let ferment for 8-10 hours until bubbly.
Grease idli molds. Pour batter into molds, filling each 3/4 full.
Steam in an idli steamer or pressure cooker (without whistle) for 10-12 minutes until cooked.
Remove idlis with a spoon and serve hot with sambar and coconut chutney.

recipes.name: Medu Vada
recipes.description: Crispy South Indian lentil donuts, served with sambar and chutney.
instructions: Soak 1 cup urad dal for 4 hours. Drain and blend with a pinch of salt and 1/4 tsp cumin seeds into a smooth, thick batter.
Heat oil in a deep pan. Wet your hands, take a portion of batter, and shape into a donut with a hole in the center.
Carefully slide vadas into hot oil and fry until golden and crisp (about 4-5 minutes per side).
Drain on paper towels. Serve hot with sambar and coconut chutney.

recipes.name: Manchurian
recipes.description: Indo-Chinese fried vegetable balls in a thick, savory sauce.
instructions: For balls: Mix 1 cup grated cabbage, 1/2 cup grated carrots, 1/4 cup chopped beans, 1/4 cup cornflour, 1/4 cup all-purpose flour, 1 tsp soy sauce, and salt. Form into small balls.
Deep-fry balls in hot oil until golden (about 4-5 minutes). Drain and set aside.
For sauce: Heat 1 tbsp oil in a pan. Add 1 tsp ginger paste, 1 tsp garlic paste, and 1 chopped green chili. Sauté for 1 minute.
Add 1/2 cup chopped bell peppers and 1 tbsp soy sauce, 1 tbsp tomato ketchup, 1 tsp red chili sauce, and 1 cup water. Simmer for 5 minutes.
Mix 1 tbsp cornflour with 2 tbsp water and add to the sauce to thicken. Add fried balls and toss to coat.
Garnish with spring onions and serve with fried rice or noodles.
